title: How to Prepare a Nursery for Twins

steps.headline: Choose the right crib (or cribs) for your twins.
steps.description: Many parents of twins have their babies share a crib, at least for the first few days. This is safe according the American Academy of Pediatrics, but note that it isn’t a long-term solution. Eventually they’ll need their own sleeping spaces and these cribs should meet government safety standards. Cribs should have a firm, tight-fitting mattress. There should be no more than 2 ⁄8 inches (60 mm) between crib slats and no slats should be broken or missing. If a crib has corner posts, they shouldn’t be more than ⁄16 inch (1.6 mm) high. Cribs should not have cutouts in the headboard or footboard.

steps.headline: Place cribs away from windows.
steps.description: Not only does being near a window introduce disruptive light into the baby’s space, but it can also be dangerous. Drafts, possible falling screens, and drapery and blind accessories can all be hazardous to a baby.

steps.headline: Remove all cords from the crib area.
steps.description: Lamp cords, baby monitor cords, and cords attached to other devices or accessories can all be dangerous. Keep them several feet away from a baby’s crib.

steps.headline: Avoid hanging decorations near the crib.
steps.description: If you have a mobile hanging above a crib, make sure it’s out of arm’s reach and baby safe. Don’t place decorations with loose ribbons or other details near enough for a baby to touch and pull down.

steps.headline: Banish toys and blankets from inside the crib.
steps.description: Once your babies are home and ready to start sleeping in their cribs, follow standard safety guidelines. Use a tight, fitted sheet and keep all blankets and stuffed animals out of the crib when babies are sleeping. Swaddling them and keeping them on their back is the best approach for newborns.

parts.name: Setting up the Remaining Nursery Items

steps.headline: Keep simplicity in mind when decorating.
steps.description: You’ll likely want to redecorate once your children start to form their own likes and dislikes or if they eventually move to separate rooms, so don’t spend too much time on creating elaborate decor. Instead, go for complementary colors and neutrals that make it easy to mix and match blankets and other accessories.

steps.headline: Buy a changing table that serves a dual purpose.
steps.description: You can avoid back pain and make life easier by investing in a good diaper-changing station, but don't limit yourself to pieces strictly defined as changing tables. You may even be able to use something you already have in the house. Think outside the box by placing a comfortable and secure changing pad on top of a dresser, bureau or desk that sits at the right height. As opposed to a standard changing table, items like armoires, dressers and shelves can be used for multiple purposes, such as storing clothes and diapers, and can be used in (or returned to) other rooms in your house later on.

steps.headline: Add a rocking chair to your nursery.
steps.description: When it comes to feeding time and soothing babies back to sleep, a rocking chair or glider will get hours of use. Check with your fellow parents for recommendations, read online reviews, and visit a few stores so that you have a chance to try the chair out before you buy.

steps.headline: Install a smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector.
steps.description: Make sure your nursery is as safe as possible by placing standard warning devices in the bedroom or in the hallway outside. Check the smoke alarm once a month by pushing the test button and discard smoke alarms that are over 10 years old. For carbon monoxide detectors, check the manufacturer's instructions.

steps.headline: Babyproof the nursery.
steps.description: Even though your children won’t be mobile for a while yet, it’s a good idea to make the room as safe as possible and minimize the possibility of toppling items from the beginning. Anchor all heavy furniture items to the wall and install safety latches on low drawers. Cover electrical outlets with childproof covers. Place padding over any sharp furniture corners. Make sure there are no hanging drapes or cords and avoid freestanding lamps.

steps.headline: Save money on nursery items where you can.
steps.description: Because twins are more expensive, you’ll probably want to look for ways to save money without sacrificing quality or comfort. Borrowing items from friends and family can help you save quite a bit, especially on larger items like cribs. If you’re close to anyone with older children, check with them to see if they have any useful items that are still in good shape that they wouldn’t mind lending to you. Check second hand stores, garage sales or online marketplaces for lightly used items -- you never know when you might find a great deal. Consider buying items that convert or expand. A crib that converts to a toddler bed is a smart investment, for example.

parts.name: Optimizing Storage Space in Your Nursery

steps.headline: Be creative when it comes to storing baby clothes.
steps.description: Use under-the-crib storage boxes, storage baskets and storage ottomans. You can even install a double closet rod to expand clothing storage even further.

steps.headline: Incorporate storage space for books and toys.
steps.description: There’s no doubt your children will require lots of comforting and fun items in addition to the basic necessities, so figure out how to make room for everything. Consider installing floor to ceiling shelving even if you’re not short on space. You can also use hanging back-of-the-door storage pockets for miscellaneous items like toys, bibs, bath towels and diaper changing accoutrement. Opt for storage baskets for toys as well as clothes if the nursery is too small to accommodate multiple storage shelves. These can be moved around easily and make clean-up time easier.

steps.headline: Repurpose diaper boxes to serve as storage containers.
steps.description: Since you’ll be going through quite a few diapers, give the large boxes they come in a second life by using them to house miscellaneous nursery items. If you want to keep these boxes filled with the diapers themselves, get crafty and decorate the box so that the room looks cute rather than cluttered.
